s.text: We don't even have to be told what the bill is anymore; we may not know all the details, but we know--and the pictures tell us--that it's designed to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and unstable loners.

We don't even have to be told what the bill is anymore; we may not know all the details, but we know--and the pictures tell us--that it's designed to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and unstable loners.
The message here is that even the most optimistic person in America can be struck down by a gunman.

The spot is aimed at swing voters--suburbanites, Republican women, and fiscal conservatives who disagree with the dominant Republican position on issues like guns and abortion--precisely the kind of people Jim and Sarah Brady were when he was serving as President Reagan's press secretary in 1981.
Jim Brady's slow words hit like soft hammer blows--"It was over in a moment, but the pain lasts forever."
The first scene is the familiar news footage from 1981: A smiling and waving Ronald Reagan outside the Washington Hilton takes a bullet to the chest.
